title: Section C
passagesOne: Questions 46 to 50 are based on the following passage.

questionsOne.Statement: What do we learn from the passage about ebikes?

Options.text: Their health benefits and fun values outweigh their cost.
They did not catch public attention in the United States until the 1990s.
They did not become popular until the emergence of improved batteries.
Their widespread use is attributable to people's environmental awareness.

questionsOne.Statement: What brought about the boost in ebike sales in Europe at the beginning of the century?

Options.text: Updated technology of bike manufacture.
The falling prices of ebike batteries.
Changed fashion in short-distance travel.
The rising costs for making electric cars.

questionsOne.Statement: What is the prospect of the bike industry according to Ryan Rzepecki?

Options.text: More will be invested in bike battery research.
The sales of ebikes will increase.
It will profit from ebike sharing.
It will make a difference in people's daily lives.

questionsOne.Statement: What prevented Chris Cocalis from developing ebikes sooner?

Options.text: Retailers' refusal to deal in ebikes.
High profits from conventional bikes.
Users' concern about risks of ebike riding.
His focus on selling costly mountain bikes.

questionsOne.Statement: What makes Chris Cocalis believe there is a greater opportunity for ebike sales?

Options.text: The further lowering of ebike prices.
The public's concern for their health.
The increasing interest in mountain climbing.
The younger generation's pursuit of comfortable riding.

passagesTwo: Questions 51 to 55 are based on the following passage.

questionsTwo.Statement: Why did politicians use the two terms “global warming” and “climate change”?

Options.text: To sway public opinion of the impact of human activities on Earth.
To more accurately describe the consequences of human activities.
To win more popular votes in their campaign activities.
To assure the public of the safety of existing industries.

questionsTwo.Statement: As used in a National Academy of Sciences report, the term “climate change” differs from “global warming” in that ______.

Options.text: it sounds less vague
it looks more scientific
it covers more phenomena
it is much closer to reality

questionsTwo.Statement: What did industrialists of the late 20th century resort to in order to mislead Americans?

Options.text: Made-up survey results.
Hired climate experts.
False research findings.
Deliberate choice of words.

questionsTwo.Statement: Why did NASA choose the term “climate change”?

Options.text: To obtain more funds.
For greater precision.
For political needs.
To avoid debate.

questionsTwo.Statement: What is the author's final conclusion?

Options.text: Global warming is the more accurate term.
Accuracy of terminology matters in science.
Human activities have serious effects on Earth.
Politics interferes with serious scientific debate.
